Cards.Title: DDH (Developmental Dysplasia of the Hip)
Cards.Pathophysiology: Abnormal development of the hip joint, where the femoral head fails to align properly with the acetabulum.
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Asymmetry of thigh/gluteal folds, limited abduction, positive Ortolani/Barlow tests, leg length discrepancy.
Cards.Diagnostics: Physical exam, ultrasonography in infants under 6 months, X-rays in older children.
Cards.Treatment: Pavlik harness for infants; closed reduction and spica casting for older infants/children.
Cards.Nursing Care: Educate parents on harness care, monitor skin integrity, ensure proper hip positioning.
Hint: Focus on understanding the pathophysiology: Abnormal development of the hip joint, where the femoral head fails to align properly with the acetabulum.
Key symptoms include: Asymmetry of thigh/gluteal folds, limited abduction.
Remember treatments like: Pavlik harness for infants; closed reduction and spica casting for older infants/children..

Cards.Title: DMD (Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy)
Cards.Pathophysiology: X-linked recessive disorder causing absence of dystrophin protein, leading to progressive muscle degeneration.
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Delayed motor milestones, Gower's sign, calf pseudohypertrophy, progressive weakness.
Cards.Diagnostics: Elevated creatine kinase (CK) levels, genetic testing, muscle biopsy.
Cards.Treatment: Corticosteroids to slow progression, physical therapy, assistive devices.
Cards.Nursing Care: Support respiratory function, monitor for cardiac complications, assist with mobility aids.
Hint: Focus on understanding the pathophysiology: X-linked recessive disorder causing absence of dystrophin protein, leading to progressive muscle degeneration.
Key symptoms include: Delayed motor milestones, Gower's sign.
Remember treatments like: Corticosteroids to slow progression, physical therapy.

Cards.Title: CP (Cerebral Palsy)
Cards.Pathophysiology: Non-progressive motor dysfunction due to brain injury or malformation during development.
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Spasticity, delayed motor milestones, poor coordination, abnormal muscle tone.
Cards.Diagnostics: Developmental screening, neuroimaging (MRI or CT), and neurological exam.
Cards.Treatment: Physical and occupational therapy, antispasmodic medications (baclofen), orthopedic surgeries.
Cards.Nursing Care: Encourage mobility, prevent contractures, support family with resources and adaptive strategies.
Hint: Focus on understanding the pathophysiology: Non-progressive motor dysfunction due to brain injury or malformation during development.
Key symptoms include: Spasticity, delayed motor milestones.
Remember treatments like: Physical and occupational therapy, antispasmodic medications (baclofen).

Cards.Title: JIA (Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis)
Cards.Pathophysiology: Autoimmune inflammation of joints, leading to swelling, pain, and potential joint damage.
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Joint stiffness (worse in the morning), swelling, pain, fever, rash.
Cards.Diagnostics: Elevated ESR, CRP, and ANA; imaging for joint damage.
Cards.Treatment: NSAIDs, DMARDs (methotrexate), biologics (etanercept), physical therapy.
Cards.Nursing Care: Promote joint mobility, pain management, educate families about medication side effects.
Hint: Focus on understanding the pathophysiology: Autoimmune inflammation of joints, leading to swelling, pain, and potential joint damage.
Key symptoms include: Joint stiffness (worse in the morning), swelling.
Remember treatments like: NSAIDs, DMARDs (methotrexate).

Cards.Title: Scoliosis
Cards.Pathophysiology: Lateral curvature of the spine >10 degrees, potentially idiopathic or secondary to neuromuscular conditions.
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Uneven shoulders/hips, rib hump, back pain.
Cards.Diagnostics: Adam’s forward bend test, X-rays for Cobb angle measurement.
Cards.Treatment: Bracing for moderate curves, surgical correction for severe cases (>40 degrees).
Cards.Nursing Care: Postoperative care includes pain management, promoting mobility, monitoring for complications (e.g., infection).
Hint: Focus on understanding the pathophysiology: Lateral curvature of the spine >10 degrees, potentially idiopathic or secondary to neuromuscular conditions.
Key symptoms include: Uneven shoulders/hips, rib hump.
Remember treatments like: Bracing for moderate curves, surgical correction for severe cases (>40 degrees)..

Cards.Title: IICP (Increased Intracranial Pressure)
Cards.Pathophysiology: Elevated pressure within the skull, often due to trauma, infection, tumor, or hydrocephalus, leading to decreased cerebral perfusion.
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Bulging fontanel in infants, headache, vomiting, altered LOC, bradycardia, hypertension, irregular respirations (Cushing’s triad).
Cards.Diagnostics: CT/MRI to identify cause, lumbar puncture contraindicated if suspected herniation.
Cards.Treatment: Address underlying cause (e.g., shunt for hydrocephalus, surgery for tumor), medications (mannitol, corticosteroids).
Cards.Nursing Care: Maintain head-of-bed at 30 degrees, monitor neurologic status, avoid activities that increase ICP (e.g., coughing).
Hint: Focus on understanding the pathophysiology: Elevated pressure within the skull, often due to trauma, infection, tumor, or hydrocephalus, leading to decreased cerebral perfusion.
Key symptoms include: Bulging fontanel in infants, headache.
Remember treatments like: Address underlying cause (e.g., shunt for hydrocephalus.

Cards.Title: Meningitis
Cards.Pathophysiology: Inflammation of the meninges caused by bacterial or viral infection, leading to potential neurological damage.
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Fever, nuchal rigidity, photophobia, altered LOC, seizures, positive Kernig and Brudzinski signs.
Cards.Diagnostics: Lumbar puncture (increased WBCs, decreased glucose in bacterial meningitis), blood cultures.
Cards.Treatment: Antibiotics for bacterial meningitis, supportive care for viral meningitis, corticosteroids to reduce inflammation.
Cards.Nursing Care: Initiate droplet precautions, monitor for signs of IICP, administer medications promptly.
Hint: Focus on understanding the pathophysiology: Inflammation of the meninges caused by bacterial or viral infection, leading to potential neurological damage.
Key symptoms include: Fever, nuchal rigidity.
Remember treatments like: Antibiotics for bacterial meningitis, supportive care for viral meningitis.

Cards.Title: Spina Bifida
Cards.Pathophysiology: Neural tube defect resulting in incomplete closure of the vertebral column, with varying severity (occulta, meningocele, myelomeningocele).
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Sac-like protrusion on the back, weakness/paralysis below the defect, hydrocephalus in severe cases.
Cards.Diagnostics: Prenatal ultrasound, elevated alpha-fetoprotein in maternal blood, postnatal imaging.
Cards.Treatment: Surgical repair, management of complications (e.g., shunt for hydrocephalus, bladder/bowel training).
Cards.Nursing Care: Protect sac preoperatively, monitor for infection, teach families about long-term care and assistive devices.
Hint: Focus on understanding the pathophysiology: Neural tube defect resulting in incomplete closure of the vertebral column, with varying severity (occulta, meningocele, myelomeningocele).
Key symptoms include: Sac-like protrusion on the back, weakness/paralysis below the defect.
Remember treatments like: Surgical repair, management of complications (e.g..

Cards.Title: Seizures
Cards.Pathophysiology: Abnormal electrical activity in the brain, leading to motor, sensory, or behavioral manifestations.
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Vary by type (tonic-clonic, absence, focal); aura may precede some seizures.
Cards.Diagnostics: EEG, MRI, blood tests to identify underlying causes (e.g., infection, metabolic disorder).
Cards.Treatment: Antiepileptic drugs (e.g., phenytoin, levetiracetam), ketogenic diet, surgery for refractory cases.
Cards.Nursing Care: Ensure seizure precautions, monitor during and after seizures (time and type), educate about medication adherence.
Hint: Focus on understanding the pathophysiology: Abnormal electrical activity in the brain, leading to motor, sensory, or behavioral manifestations.
Key symptoms include: Vary by type (tonic-clonic, absence.
Remember treatments like: Antiepileptic drugs (e.g., phenytoin.

Cards.Title: SIADH (Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone)
Cards.Pathophysiology: Excess ADH secretion leads to water retention, dilutional hyponatremia, and potential cerebral edema.
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Low urine output, hyponatremia (confusion, headache, seizures), weight gain, edema.
Cards.Diagnostics: Low serum sodium/osmolality, high urine osmolality, elevated ADH levels.
Cards.Treatment: Fluid restriction, hypertonic saline for severe hyponatremia, medications (demeclocycline to inhibit ADH).
Cards.Nursing Care: Monitor I&O, restrict fluids, monitor neurologic status, educate families about managing fluid intake.
Hint: Focus on understanding the pathophysiology: Excess ADH secretion leads to water retention, dilutional hyponatremia, and potential cerebral edema.
Key symptoms include: Low urine output, hyponatremia (confusion.
Remember treatments like: Fluid restriction, hypertonic saline for severe hyponatremia.

Cards.Title: EOL Care
Cards.Pathophysiology: Focuses on symptom management and quality of life for terminal illnesses, addressing physical, emotional, and spiritual needs.
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Pain, dyspnea, fatigue, emotional distress, and other terminal phase symptoms.
Cards.Diagnostics: Symptom assessments; no specific diagnostics as the focus is palliative.
Cards.Treatment: Pain management (opioids), oxygen therapy, psychosocial support, hospice care.
Cards.Nursing Care: Provide comfort measures, involve family in care, address psychosocial needs, and support bereavement.
Hint: Focus on understanding the pathophysiology: Focuses on symptom management and quality of life for terminal illnesses, addressing physical, emotional, and spiritual needs.
Key symptoms include: Pain, dyspnea.
Remember treatments like: Pain management (opioids), oxygen therapy.

Cards.Title: Wilms Tumor
Cards.Pathophysiology: Malignant renal tumor in children, often unilateral and associated with genetic syndromes.
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Abdominal mass, hematuria, hypertension, fever.
Cards.Diagnostics: Abdominal ultrasound, CT/MRI, biopsy.
Cards.Treatment: Surgical nephrectomy, chemotherapy, sometimes radiation therapy.
Cards.Nursing Care: Avoid palpating the abdomen (to prevent tumor rupture), postoperative care, monitor for infection.
Hint: Focus on understanding the pathophysiology: Malignant renal tumor in children, often unilateral and associated with genetic syndromes.
Key symptoms include: Abdominal mass, hematuria.
Remember treatments like: Surgical nephrectomy, chemotherapy.

Cards.Title: Leukemia
Cards.Pathophysiology: Cancer of blood-forming tissues, leading to excessive production of immature white blood cells, crowding out normal cells.
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Fatigue, fever, pallor, bruising, bleeding, bone/joint pain, recurrent infections.
Cards.Diagnostics: CBC with differential (anemia, thrombocytopenia, leukocytosis), bone marrow biopsy.
Cards.Treatment: Chemotherapy, stem cell transplant, supportive therapies (e.g., transfusions).
Cards.Nursing Care: Monitor for infection, manage side effects of chemotherapy, provide emotional support to family.
Hint: Focus on understanding the pathophysiology: Cancer of blood-forming tissues, leading to excessive production of immature white blood cells, crowding out normal cells.
Key symptoms include: Fatigue, fever.
Remember treatments like: Chemotherapy, stem cell transplant.

Cards.Title: Tumor Lysis Syndrome
Cards.Pathophysiology: Rapid breakdown of tumor cells after chemotherapy, leading to electrolyte imbalances (hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, hypocalcemia) and kidney damage.
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Nausea, vomiting, muscle cramps, arrhythmias, renal failure.
Cards.Diagnostics: Blood tests (electrolytes, BUN/creatinine), ECG for cardiac changes.
Cards.Treatment: Aggressive hydration, allopurinol or rasburicase to manage uric acid, electrolyte correction.
Cards.Nursing Care: Monitor electrolyte levels, ensure adequate hydration, assess for signs of cardiac/renal complications.
Hint: Focus on understanding the pathophysiology: Rapid breakdown of tumor cells after chemotherapy, leading to electrolyte imbalances (hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, hypocalcemia) and kidney damage.
Key symptoms include: Nausea, vomiting.
Remember treatments like: Aggressive hydration, allopurinol or rasburicase to manage uric acid.

Cards.Title: TEF (Tracheoesophageal Fistula)
Cards.Pathophysiology: Congenital connection between the trachea and esophagus, often associated with esophageal atresia.
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Excessive salivation, choking, cyanosis during feeding, respiratory distress.
Cards.Diagnostics: Inability to pass an NG tube into the stomach, contrast imaging.
Cards.Treatment: Surgical correction (ligation of fistula and esophageal repair).
Cards.Nursing Care: Maintain NPO status preoperatively, provide suctioning, monitor for aspiration and respiratory distress.
Hint: Focus on understanding the pathophysiology: Congenital connection between the trachea and esophagus, often associated with esophageal atresia.
Key symptoms include: Excessive salivation, choking.
Remember treatments like: Surgical correction (ligation of fistula and esophageal repair)..

Cards.Title: Hirschsprung Disease
Cards.Pathophysiology: Congenital absence of ganglion cells in the colon, causing a lack of peristalsis and intestinal obstruction.
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Failure to pass meconium within 48 hours, abdominal distension, bilious vomiting, constipation.
Cards.Diagnostics: Rectal biopsy (absence of ganglion cells), contrast enema.
Cards.Treatment: Surgical resection of the aganglionic segment (pull-through procedure).
Cards.Nursing Care: Monitor for signs of enterocolitis, manage ostomy care if applicable, provide dietary guidance post-surgery.
Hint: Focus on understanding the pathophysiology: Congenital absence of ganglion cells in the colon, causing a lack of peristalsis and intestinal obstruction.
Key symptoms include: Failure to pass meconium within 48 hours, abdominal distension.
Remember treatments like: Surgical resection of the aganglionic segment (pull-through procedure)..

Cards.Title: GER (Gastroesophageal Reflux)
Cards.Pathophysiology: Incompetence of the lower esophageal sphincter, leading to retrograde flow of stomach contents into the esophagus.
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Spitting up, irritability, poor feeding, failure to thrive, respiratory symptoms (e.g., wheezing).
Cards.Diagnostics: pH probe, esophageal manometry, upper GI series.
Cards.Treatment: Small frequent feedings, thickened formula, medications (H2 blockers, PPIs), surgical intervention (Nissen fundoplication) in severe cases.
Cards.Nursing Care: Educate parents about positioning after feeding, monitor for aspiration.
Hint: Focus on understanding the pathophysiology: Incompetence of the lower esophageal sphincter, leading to retrograde flow of stomach contents into the esophagus.
Key symptoms include: Spitting up, irritability.
Remember treatments like: Small frequent feedings, thickened formula.

Cards.Title: Colic
Cards.Pathophysiology: Likely multifactorial; thought to involve gastrointestinal discomfort and hypersensitivity to stimuli.
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Excessive, inconsolable crying for more than 3 hours/day, more than 3 days/week.
Cards.Diagnostics: Clinical diagnosis based on history and exclusion of other causes.
Cards.Treatment: Parental reassurance, dietary changes (if breastfeeding), anti-gas drops (simethicone).
Cards.Nursing Care: Teach soothing techniques, provide emotional support to parents.
Hint: Focus on understanding the pathophysiology: Likely multifactorial; thought to involve gastrointestinal discomfort and hypersensitivity to stimuli.
Key symptoms include: Excessive, inconsolable crying for more than 3 hours/day.
Remember treatments like: Parental reassurance, dietary changes (if breastfeeding).

Cards.Title: Intussusception
Cards.Pathophysiology: Telescoping of one part of the intestine into another, causing obstruction and ischemia.
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Sudden abdominal pain, 'currant jelly' stools, sausage-shaped abdominal mass, vomiting.
Cards.Diagnostics: Abdominal ultrasound, air or contrast enema (both diagnostic and therapeutic).
Cards.Treatment: Non-surgical reduction via enema, surgical intervention if unsuccessful.
Cards.Nursing Care: Monitor for recurrence, assess stool patterns, educate parents about post-procedure care.
Hint: Focus on understanding the pathophysiology: Telescoping of one part of the intestine into another, causing obstruction and ischemia.
Key symptoms include: Sudden abdominal pain, 'currant jelly' stools.
Remember treatments like: Non-surgical reduction via enema, surgical intervention if unsuccessful..

Cards.Title: Biliary Atresia
Cards.Pathophysiology: Congenital obstruction or absence of bile ducts, leading to cholestasis and liver damage.
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Jaundice persisting beyond 2 weeks of life, pale stools, dark urine, hepatomegaly.
Cards.Diagnostics: Liver biopsy, cholangiogram, elevated bilirubin levels.
Cards.Treatment: Kasai procedure (hepatoportoenterostomy) to restore bile flow; liver transplant if unsuccessful.
Cards.Nursing Care: Monitor liver function, provide nutritional support (fat-soluble vitamins), educate parents on postoperative care.
Hint: Focus on understanding the pathophysiology: Congenital obstruction or absence of bile ducts, leading to cholestasis and liver damage.
Key symptoms include: Jaundice persisting beyond 2 weeks of life, pale stools.
Remember treatments like: Kasai procedure (hepatoportoenterostomy) to restore bile flow; liver transplant if unsuccessful..

Cards.Title: Dehydration
Cards.Pathophysiology: Fluid loss exceeds intake, leading to electrolyte imbalances and hypovolemia.
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Dry mucous membranes, decreased urine output, sunken fontanels (infants), tachycardia, poor skin turgor.
Cards.Diagnostics: Serum electrolyte levels, urinalysis (specific gravity), clinical signs.
Cards.Treatment: Oral rehydration solution (mild to moderate), IV fluids (severe dehydration).
Cards.Nursing Care: Monitor fluid status (I&O, weight), educate caregivers about hydration, assess for signs of shock.
Hint: Focus on understanding the pathophysiology: Fluid loss exceeds intake, leading to electrolyte imbalances and hypovolemia.
Key symptoms include: Dry mucous membranes, decreased urine output.
Remember treatments like: Oral rehydration solution (mild to moderate), IV fluids (severe dehydration)..

Cards.Title: Burns
Cards.Pathophysiology: Tissue damage due to thermal, chemical, electrical, or radiation exposure, resulting in fluid loss, infection risk, and metabolic demands.
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Redness, blistering, pain (superficial burns); charred skin, numbness (deep burns).
Cards.Diagnostics: Assessment of burn depth and total body surface area (TBSA).
Cards.Treatment: Fluid resuscitation (Parkland formula), wound care, pain management, infection prevention.
Cards.Nursing Care: Monitor for signs of infection, manage pain, ensure proper nutrition for wound healing.
Hint: Focus on understanding the pathophysiology: Tissue damage due to thermal, chemical, electrical, or radiation exposure, resulting in fluid loss, infection risk, and metabolic demands.
Key symptoms include: Redness, blistering.
Remember treatments like: Fluid resuscitation (Parkland formula), wound care.

Cards.Title: UTI (Urinary Tract Infection)
Cards.Pathophysiology: Infection of the urinary tract, commonly caused by E. coli, leading to inflammation and irritation.
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Dysuria, fever, abdominal pain, hematuria, enuresis in children.
Cards.Diagnostics: Urinalysis (WBCs, nitrites), urine culture.
Cards.Treatment: Antibiotics (e.g., amoxicillin, cephalosporins).
Cards.Nursing Care: Encourage fluid intake, teach proper perineal hygiene, educate on completing the antibiotic course.
Hint: Focus on understanding the pathophysiology: Infection of the urinary tract, commonly caused by E.
Key symptoms include: Dysuria, fever.
Remember treatments like: Antibiotics (e.g., amoxicillin.

Cards.Title: Nephrotic Syndrome
Cards.Pathophysiology: Increased glomerular permeability leads to protein loss in urine, hypoalbuminemia, and edema.
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Periorbital edema, ascites, proteinuria, frothy urine.
Cards.Diagnostics: Urinalysis (proteinuria), serum albumin levels, renal biopsy if needed.
Cards.Treatment: Corticosteroids, diuretics, albumin infusions, sodium restriction.
Cards.Nursing Care: Monitor fluid status, prevent infections, educate families on dietary restrictions and medication compliance.
Hint: Focus on understanding the pathophysiology: Increased glomerular permeability leads to protein loss in urine, hypoalbuminemia, and edema.
Key symptoms include: Periorbital edema, ascites.
Remember treatments like: Corticosteroids, diuretics.

Cards.Title: AGN (Acute Glomerulonephritis)
Cards.Pathophysiology: Inflammation of glomeruli, often post-streptococcal, causing impaired kidney filtration.
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Hematuria (tea-colored urine), hypertension, edema, oliguria.
Cards.Diagnostics: Elevated ASO titer, urinalysis (hematuria, proteinuria), serum creatinine/BUN.
Cards.Treatment: Supportive care (antihypertensives, diuretics), fluid and sodium restriction.
Cards.Nursing Care: Monitor BP and urine output, educate on dietary restrictions, assess for complications (e.g., encephalopathy).
Hint: Focus on understanding the pathophysiology: Inflammation of glomeruli, often post-streptococcal, causing impaired kidney filtration.
Key symptoms include: Hematuria (tea-colored urine), hypertension.
Remember treatments like: Supportive care (antihypertensives, diuretics).

Cards.Title: Diabetes
Cards.Pathophysiology: Impaired insulin production (Type 1) or insulin resistance (Type 2), leading to hyperglycemia.
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Polyuria, polydipsia, polyphagia, weight loss (Type 1), acanthosis nigricans (Type 2).
Cards.Diagnostics: Blood glucose levels, HbA1c, fasting glucose, oral glucose tolerance test.
Cards.Treatment: Insulin therapy (Type 1), oral hypoglycemics (Type 2), dietary changes, exercise.
Cards.Nursing Care: Educate families on blood glucose monitoring, insulin administration, and hypoglycemia prevention.
Hint: Focus on understanding the pathophysiology: Impaired insulin production (Type 1) or insulin resistance (Type 2), leading to hyperglycemia.
Key symptoms include: Polyuria, polydipsia.
Remember treatments like: Insulin therapy (Type 1), oral hypoglycemics (Type 2).

Cards.Title: Hypospadias
Cards.Pathophysiology: Congenital condition where the urethral opening is on the underside of the penis rather than the tip.
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Abnormal urethral placement, downward curvature (chordee), difficulty with urination.
Cards.Diagnostics: Physical examination at birth.
Cards.Treatment: Surgical correction, typically performed before 18 months of age.
Cards.Nursing Care: Educate parents about avoiding circumcision before surgery, monitor post-surgical site for infection, and ensure urinary drainage.
Hint: Focus on understanding the pathophysiology: Congenital condition where the urethral opening is on the underside of the penis rather than the tip.
Key symptoms include: Abnormal urethral placement, downward curvature (chordee).
Remember treatments like: Surgical correction, typically performed before 18 months of age..

Cards.Title: Testicular Torsion
Cards.Pathophysiology: Twisting of the spermatic cord, cutting off blood supply to the testicle, causing ischemia.
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Sudden severe scrotal pain, swelling, nausea, vomiting, and absence of cremasteric reflex.
Cards.Diagnostics: Doppler ultrasound, physical exam.
Cards.Treatment: Surgical detorsion and fixation (orchiopexy); testicle removal if necrotic.
Cards.Nursing Care: Provide pre- and post-op care, educate parents and adolescents on the importance of prompt treatment.
Hint: Focus on understanding the pathophysiology: Twisting of the spermatic cord, cutting off blood supply to the testicle, causing ischemia.
Key symptoms include: Sudden severe scrotal pain, swelling.
Remember treatments like: Surgical detorsion and fixation (orchiopexy); testicle removal if necrotic..

Cards.Title: Enuresis
Cards.Pathophysiology: Repeated involuntary urination, often nocturnal, beyond the age of bladder control development.
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Bedwetting in children over 5 years old, often without underlying pathology.
Cards.Diagnostics: History and physical exam, urinalysis to rule out infection or diabetes.
Cards.Treatment: Behavioral strategies, enuresis alarms, medications (desmopressin, imipramine).
Cards.Nursing Care: Educate families on behavior modification techniques, encourage limiting fluids before bedtime, provide emotional support to reduce stigma.
Hint: Focus on understanding the pathophysiology: Repeated involuntary urination, often nocturnal, beyond the age of bladder control development.
Key symptoms include: Bedwetting in children over 5 years old, often without underlying pathology..
Remember treatments like: Behavioral strategies, enuresis alarms.

Cards.Title: TOF (Tetralogy of Fallot)
Cards.Pathophysiology: Congenital heart defect consisting of four anomalies: pulmonary stenosis, right ventricular hypertrophy, overriding aorta, and ventricular septal defect (VSD).
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Cyanosis (especially during crying or feeding), 'tet spells,' clubbing of fingers, poor growth.
Cards.Diagnostics: Echocardiogram, chest X-ray ('boot-shaped heart'), cardiac catheterization.
Cards.Treatment: Surgical repair (complete or staged), prostaglandin E1 infusion to maintain ductus arteriosus patency pre-surgery.
Cards.Nursing Care: Monitor oxygen levels, teach parents to manage 'tet spells' (e.g., knee-chest position), provide postoperative care.
Hint: Focus on understanding the pathophysiology: Congenital heart defect consisting of four anomalies: pulmonary stenosis, right ventricular hypertrophy, overriding aorta, and ventricular septal defect (VSD).
Key symptoms include: Cyanosis (especially during crying or feeding), 'tet spells,' clubbing of fingers.
Remember treatments like: Surgical repair (complete or staged), prostaglandin E1 infusion to maintain ductus arteriosus patency pre-surgery..

Cards.Title: PDA (Patent Ductus Arteriosus)
Cards.Pathophysiology: Failure of the ductus arteriosus to close after birth, causing left-to-right shunting of blood.
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Machinery-like murmur, bounding pulses, tachypnea, poor feeding.
Cards.Diagnostics: Echocardiogram, chest X-ray.
Cards.Treatment: Indomethacin or ibuprofen to close PDA (if no CHF), surgical ligation or catheterization for closure.
Cards.Nursing Care: Monitor respiratory status, provide feeding support, educate families on postoperative expectations.
Hint: Focus on understanding the pathophysiology: Failure of the ductus arteriosus to close after birth, causing left-to-right shunting of blood.
Key symptoms include: Machinery-like murmur, bounding pulses.
Remember treatments like: Indomethacin or ibuprofen to close PDA (if no CHF), surgical ligation or catheterization for closure..

Cards.Title: Transposition of the Great Arteries (TGA)
Cards.Pathophysiology: The aorta and pulmonary artery are switched, leading to oxygen-poor blood being circulated systemically.
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Cyanosis, tachypnea, poor feeding, heart failure signs.
Cards.Diagnostics: Echocardiogram, chest X-ray ('egg-shaped heart').
Cards.Treatment: Prostaglandin E1 to maintain ductus arteriosus, balloon atrial septostomy, corrective surgery (arterial switch).
Cards.Nursing Care: Monitor oxygenation, manage prostaglandin infusion, provide postoperative care and support.
Hint: Focus on understanding the pathophysiology: The aorta and pulmonary artery are switched, leading to oxygen-poor blood being circulated systemically.
Key symptoms include: Cyanosis, tachypnea.
Remember treatments like: Prostaglandin E1 to maintain ductus arteriosus, balloon atrial septostomy.

Cards.Title: Coarctation of the Aorta
Cards.Pathophysiology: Narrowing of the aorta, leading to increased pressure before the narrowing and decreased pressure after.
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Elevated blood pressure in arms, diminished pulses in legs, murmur, signs of heart failure in infants.
Cards.Diagnostics: Blood pressure measurements in all extremities, echocardiogram, MRI.
Cards.Treatment: Balloon angioplasty, surgical repair.
Cards.Nursing Care: Monitor BP in upper and lower extremities, manage antihypertensive medications, provide post-op care.
Hint: Focus on understanding the pathophysiology: Narrowing of the aorta, leading to increased pressure before the narrowing and decreased pressure after.
Key symptoms include: Elevated blood pressure in arms, diminished pulses in legs.
Remember treatments like: Balloon angioplasty, surgical repair..

Cards.Title: Post-Op Care for Cardiac Surgery
Cards.Pathophysiology: Recovery involves managing hemodynamics, preventing complications, and supporting the child’s growth and development.
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Monitor for arrhythmias, fluid imbalances, and signs of infection.
Cards.Diagnostics: Frequent vital sign checks, chest X-ray, lab monitoring (electrolytes, CBC).
Cards.Treatment: Pain management, fluid and nutritional support, respiratory care (e.g., chest physiotherapy).
Cards.Nursing Care: Monitor for complications (e.g., tamponade, infections), educate families on activity restrictions and signs of complications.
Hint: Focus on understanding the pathophysiology: Recovery involves managing hemodynamics, preventing complications, and supporting the child’s growth and development.
Key symptoms include: Monitor for arrhythmias, fluid imbalances.
Remember treatments like: Pain management, fluid and nutritional support.

Cards.Title: Hemophilia
Cards.Pathophysiology: X-linked recessive disorder causing deficiency in clotting factors (Factor VIII in hemophilia A or Factor IX in hemophilia B), leading to impaired blood clotting.
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Prolonged bleeding, joint swelling (hemarthrosis), bruising, hematomas.
Cards.Diagnostics: Prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT), low clotting factor levels.
Cards.Treatment: Factor replacement therapy, DDAVP (desmopressin) for mild cases of hemophilia A.
Cards.Nursing Care: Avoid IM injections, provide safety education to prevent injury, administer clotting factors promptly during bleeding episodes.
Hint: Focus on understanding the pathophysiology: X-linked recessive disorder causing deficiency in clotting factors (Factor VIII in hemophilia A or Factor IX in hemophilia B), leading to impaired blood clotting.
Key symptoms include: Prolonged bleeding, joint swelling (hemarthrosis).
Remember treatments like: Factor replacement therapy, DDAVP (desmopressin) for mild cases of hemophilia A..

Cards.Title: Sickle Cell Disease
Cards.Pathophysiology: Autosomal recessive disorder causing abnormal hemoglobin (HbS), leading to sickling of red blood cells and vaso-occlusion.
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Pain crises, anemia, jaundice, swelling in hands/feet (dactylitis), infections.
Cards.Diagnostics: Hemoglobin electrophoresis, CBC (low hemoglobin, elevated reticulocyte count).
Cards.Treatment: Pain management, hydration, oxygen, blood transfusions, hydroxyurea to reduce sickling.
Cards.Nursing Care: Monitor for complications (stroke, acute chest syndrome), educate on triggers of crises, ensure vaccinations.
Hint: Focus on understanding the pathophysiology: Autosomal recessive disorder causing abnormal hemoglobin (HbS), leading to sickling of red blood cells and vaso-occlusion.
Key symptoms include: Pain crises, anemia.
Remember treatments like: Pain management, hydration.

Cards.Title: Anemia
Cards.Pathophysiology: Decreased red blood cells or hemoglobin, leading to reduced oxygen delivery to tissues.
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Fatigue, pallor, tachycardia, dizziness.
Cards.Diagnostics: CBC (low hemoglobin/hematocrit), reticulocyte count, iron studies.
Cards.Treatment: Iron supplementation for iron-deficiency anemia, blood transfusions for severe cases.
Cards.Nursing Care: Educate on iron-rich foods, monitor for side effects of supplements (e.g., constipation, black stools).
Hint: Focus on understanding the pathophysiology: Decreased red blood cells or hemoglobin, leading to reduced oxygen delivery to tissues.
Key symptoms include: Fatigue, pallor.
Remember treatments like: Iron supplementation for iron-deficiency anemia, blood transfusions for severe cases..

Cards.Title: Aplastic Anemia
Cards.Pathophysiology: Bone marrow failure resulting in pancytopenia (deficiency of all blood cell types).
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Fatigue, bruising, recurrent infections, bleeding.
Cards.Diagnostics: CBC (low RBCs, WBCs, platelets), bone marrow biopsy (hypocellular marrow).
Cards.Treatment: Immunosuppressive therapy, bone marrow transplant, blood transfusions.
Cards.Nursing Care: Monitor for infection and bleeding, provide emotional support, educate about avoiding infection risks.
Hint: Focus on understanding the pathophysiology: Bone marrow failure resulting in pancytopenia (deficiency of all blood cell types).
Key symptoms include: Fatigue, bruising.
Remember treatments like: Immunosuppressive therapy, bone marrow transplant.

Cards.Title: ATopic Dermatitis (Eczema)
Cards.Pathophysiology: Chronic inflammatory skin condition associated with genetic predisposition, allergies, and immune dysregulation.
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Dry, itchy, red patches, often on face, elbows, knees; may ooze or crust.
Cards.Diagnostics: Clinical evaluation, family history of allergies/asthma.
Cards.Treatment: Emollients, Topical corticosteroids, antihistamines for itching, avoiding triggers.
Cards.Nursing Care: Educate on skin hydration, avoidance of irritants, and proper use of medications.
Hint: Focus on understanding the pathophysiology: Chronic inflammatory skin condition associated with genetic predisposition, allergies, and immune dysregulation.
Key symptoms include: Dry, itchy.
Remember treatments like: Emollients, Topical corticosteroids.

Cards.Title: Lice (Pediculosis Capitis)
Cards.Pathophysiology: Infestation of scalp by lice, causing irritation and secondary infection.
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Intense scalp itching, visible lice or nits on hair shafts.
Cards.Diagnostics: Visual inspection.
Cards.Treatment: Pediculicides (e.g., permethrin), nit combing, laundering clothing/bedding.
Cards.Nursing Care: Teach families about lice prevention, retreatment schedule, and cleaning practices.
Hint: Focus on understanding the pathophysiology: Infestation of scalp by lice, causing irritation and secondary infection.
Key symptoms include: Intense scalp itching, visible lice or nits on hair shafts..
Remember treatments like: Pediculicides (e.g., permethrin).

Cards.Title: Cellulitis
Cards.Pathophysiology: Bacterial infection of the dermis and subcutaneous tissue, typically caused by Streptococcus or Staphylococcus species.
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Red, swollen, warm, tender area; fever, malaise.
Cards.Diagnostics: Clinical exam, wound culture in severe cases.
Cards.Treatment: Oral or IV antibiotics, elevation of affected limb.
Cards.Nursing Care: Monitor for signs of systemic infection (e.g., sepsis), educate about wound care.
Hint: Focus on understanding the pathophysiology: Bacterial infection of the dermis and subcutaneous tissue, typically caused by Streptococcus or Staphylococcus species.
Key symptoms include: Red, swollen.
Remember treatments like: Oral or IV antibiotics, elevation of affected limb..

Cards.Title: Impetigo
Cards.Pathophysiology: Superficial bacterial skin infection, often caused by Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus pyogenes.
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Honey-colored crusted lesions, typically on face or extremities, highly contagious.
Cards.Diagnostics: Clinical diagnosis, sometimes bacterial culture.
Cards.Treatment: Topical or oral antibiotics (e.g., mupirocin, cephalexin).
Cards.Nursing Care: Prevent spread by emphasizing hygiene, avoid sharing items like towels.
Hint: Focus on understanding the pathophysiology: Superficial bacterial skin infection, often caused by Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus pyogenes.
Key symptoms include: Honey-colored crusted lesions, typically on face or extremities.
Remember treatments like: Topical or oral antibiotics (e.g., mupirocin.

Cards.Title: Acne
Cards.Pathophysiology: Inflammation of pilosebaceous units due to excess sebum, bacteria (Cutibacterium acnes), and clogged pores.
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Papules, pustules, cysts on face, back, chest.
Cards.Diagnostics: Clinical examination.
Cards.Treatment: Topical retinoids, benzoyl peroxide, antibiotics (Topical or oral), isotretinoin for severe cases.
Cards.Nursing Care: Educate on skincare routine, potential side effects of medications (e.g., dryness, photosensitivity).
Hint: Focus on understanding the pathophysiology: Inflammation of pilosebaceous units due to excess sebum, bacteria (Cutibacterium acnes), and clogged pores.
Key symptoms include: Papules, pustules.
Remember treatments like: Topical retinoids, benzoyl peroxide.

Cards.Title: Down Syndrome
Cards.Pathophysiology: Genetic condition caused by trisomy 21, leading to developmental and physical delays.
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Intellectual disability, hypotonia, characteristic facial features (e.g., flat nasal bridge, upward-slanting eyes), congenital heart defects.
Cards.Diagnostics: Karyotype analysis, prenatal screening (e.g., nuchal translucency, amniocentesis).
Cards.Treatment: Supportive therapies (speech, physical, occupational), management of associated medical conditions.
Cards.Nursing Care: Monitor for congenital anomalies, provide family support, and promote developmental interventions.
Hint: Focus on understanding the pathophysiology: Genetic condition caused by trisomy 21, leading to developmental and physical delays.
Key symptoms include: Intellectual disability, hypotonia.
Remember treatments like: Supportive therapies (speech, physical.

Cards.Title: ASD (Autism Spectrum Disorder)
Cards.Pathophysiology: Neurodevelopmental disorder affecting social communication and behavior, likely due to genetic and environmental factors.
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Delayed language development, repetitive behaviors, difficulty with social interaction, sensory sensitivities.
Cards.Diagnostics: Developmental screening, Autism Diagnostic Observation Schedule (ADOS).
Cards.Treatment: Behavioral therapy (ABA), speech therapy, educational support, medications for specific symptoms.
Cards.Nursing Care: Encourage structured routines, support family with resources, and educate about early interventions.
Hint: Focus on understanding the pathophysiology: Neurodevelopmental disorder affecting social communication and behavior, likely due to genetic and environmental factors.
Key symptoms include: Delayed language development, repetitive behaviors.
Remember treatments like: Behavioral therapy (ABA), speech therapy.

Cards.Title: Fragile X Syndrome
Cards.Pathophysiology: X-linked genetic disorder caused by a mutation in the FMR1 gene, leading to intellectual and developmental disabilities.
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Intellectual disability, hyperactivity, anxiety, elongated face, large ears, macroorchidism in males.
Cards.Diagnostics: Genetic testing (FMR1 mutation analysis).
Cards.Treatment: Speech, occupational, and behavioral therapies; medications for symptoms (e.g., ADHD, anxiety).
Cards.Nursing Care: Support educational needs, provide family resources, and monitor for associated medical issues.
Hint: Focus on understanding the pathophysiology: X-linked genetic disorder caused by a mutation in the FMR1 gene, leading to intellectual and developmental disabilities.
Key symptoms include: Intellectual disability, hyperactivity.
Remember treatments like: Speech, occupational.

Cards.Title: Cognitive Impairment
Cards.Pathophysiology: Generalized delay or impairment in intellectual functioning due to genetic, environmental, or acquired factors.
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Delayed milestones, difficulty learning, social withdrawal.
Cards.Diagnostics: Developmental and cognitive assessments.
Cards.Treatment: Tailored educational programs, therapies (speech, occupational, physical).
Cards.Nursing Care: Educate families on resources, promote independence in activities of daily living (ADLs), and advocate for individualized education plans (IEPs).
Hint: Focus on understanding the pathophysiology: Generalized delay or impairment in intellectual functioning due to genetic, environmental, or acquired factors.
Key symptoms include: Delayed milestones, difficulty learning.
Remember treatments like: Tailored educational programs, therapies (speech.

Cards.Title: Asthma
Cards.Pathophysiology: Chronic inflammatory airway disorder triggered by allergens, infections, or irritants, leading to bronchoconstriction and mucus production.
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Wheezing, coughing (especially at night), shortness of breath, chest tightness.
Cards.Diagnostics: Spirometry, peak expiratory flow rates, allergen testing.
Cards.Treatment: Bronchodilators (albuterol), inhaled corticosteroids, leukotriene modifiers.
Cards.Nursing Care: Teach proper inhaler technique, develop an asthma action plan, monitor for triggers and early signs of exacerbation.
Hint: Focus on understanding the pathophysiology: Chronic inflammatory airway disorder triggered by allergens, infections, or irritants, leading to bronchoconstriction and mucus production.
Key symptoms include: Wheezing, coughing (especially at night).
Remember treatments like: Bronchodilators (albuterol), inhaled corticosteroids.

Cards.Title: CF (Cystic Fibrosis)
Cards.Pathophysiology: Autosomal recessive disorder causing defective chloride transport, leading to thick mucus in lungs, pancreas, and other organs.
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Chronic cough, recurrent respiratory infections, greasy stools, failure to thrive.
Cards.Diagnostics: Sweat chloride test, genetic testing.
Cards.Treatment: Airway clearance (chest physiotherapy), pancreatic enzyme replacement, antibiotics, high-calorie diet.
Cards.Nursing Care: Monitor respiratory function, ensure nutritional needs, educate families on infection prevention and home care.
Hint: Focus on understanding the pathophysiology: Autosomal recessive disorder causing defective chloride transport, leading to thick mucus in lungs, pancreas, and other organs.
Key symptoms include: Chronic cough, recurrent respiratory infections.
Remember treatments like: Airway clearance (chest physiotherapy), pancreatic enzyme replacement.

Cards.Title: Croup
Cards.Pathophysiology: Viral infection causing inflammation of the larynx and trachea, leading to airway narrowing.
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Barking cough, stridor, hoarseness, respiratory distress.
Cards.Diagnostics: Clinical presentation, neck X-ray ('steeple sign').
Cards.Treatment: Humidified air, corticosteroids (dexamethasone), nebulized epinephrine for severe cases.
Cards.Nursing Care: Maintain a calm environment, monitor for respiratory distress, educate parents about home care.
Hint: Focus on understanding the pathophysiology: Viral infection causing inflammation of the larynx and trachea, leading to airway narrowing.
Key symptoms include: Barking cough, stridor.
Remember treatments like: Humidified air, corticosteroids (dexamethasone).

Cards.Title: Epiglottitis
Cards.Pathophysiology: Acute bacterial infection (often Haemophilus influenzae type B) causing inflammation and swelling of the epiglottis, leading to airway obstruction.
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Sudden onset of high fever, drooling, tripod positioning, muffled voice, stridor.
Cards.Diagnostics: Lateral neck X-ray ('thumbprint sign'), clinical presentation.
Cards.Treatment: Airway management, IV antibiotics, corticosteroids.
Cards.Nursing Care: Do not attempt throat inspection, ensure emergency airway equipment is ready, administer medications promptly.
Hint: Focus on understanding the pathophysiology: Acute bacterial infection (often Haemophilus influenzae type B) causing inflammation and swelling of the epiglottis, leading to airway obstruction.
Key symptoms include: Sudden onset of high fever, drooling.
Remember treatments like: Airway management, IV antibiotics.

Cards.Title: OM (Otitis Media)
Cards.Pathophysiology: Middle ear infection, often following upper respiratory infections, caused by bacteria or viruses.
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Ear pain, fever, irritability, pulling at ears, decreased hearing.
Cards.Diagnostics: Otoscopic exam showing bulging or erythematous tympanic membrane.
Cards.Treatment: Antibiotics (amoxicillin) for bacterial infections, analgesics for pain relief.
Cards.Nursing Care: Educate families about proper medication use, encourage breastfeeding (protective against OM), monitor for complications like hearing loss.
Hint: Focus on understanding the pathophysiology: Middle ear infection, often following upper respiratory infections, caused by bacteria or viruses.
Key symptoms include: Ear pain, fever.
Remember treatments like: Antibiotics (amoxicillin) for bacterial infections, analgesics for pain relief..

Cards.Title: Varicella (Chickenpox)
Cards.Pathophysiology: Viral infection caused by the varicella-zoster virus, leading to widespread vesicular rash.
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Fever, malaise, itchy rash that progresses from macules to vesicles and crusts.
Cards.Diagnostics: Clinical presentation, polymerase chain reaction (PCR) in atypical cases.
Cards.Treatment: Supportive care (antihistamines, calamine lotion), acyclovir for high-risk patients.
Cards.Nursing Care: Isolate to prevent spread, educate on preventing scratching to avoid secondary infections, ensure vaccination for prevention.
Hint: Focus on understanding the pathophysiology: Viral infection caused by the varicella-zoster virus, leading to widespread vesicular rash.
Key symptoms include: Fever, malaise.
Remember treatments like: Supportive care (antihistamines, calamine lotion).

Cards.Title: MMR (Measles, Mumps, Rubella)
Cards.Pathophysiology: Viral illnesses caused by separate viruses, transmitted via respiratory droplets, leading to systemic manifestations.
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Measles: Fever, cough, conjunctivitis, Koplik spots, maculopapular rash. Mumps: Swollen parotid glands, fever, headache, orchitis in males. Rubella: Mild fever, rash, lymphadenopathy, teratogenic in pregnancy.
Cards.Diagnostics: Serologic testing, PCR.
Cards.Treatment: Supportive care; no specific antiviral treatment.
Cards.Nursing Care: Ensure vaccination, provide symptomatic relief, educate on infection control measures.
Hint: Focus on understanding the pathophysiology: Viral illnesses caused by separate viruses, transmitted via respiratory droplets, leading to systemic manifestations.
Key symptoms include: Measles: Fever, cough.
Remember treatments like: Supportive care; no specific antiviral treatment..

Cards.Title: 5th Disease (Erythema Infectiosum)
Cards.Pathophysiology: Viral illness caused by parvovirus B19, leading to mild systemic symptoms and rash.
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: 'Slapped cheek' rash, lacy rash on body, fever, malaise.
Cards.Diagnostics: Clinical presentation, serologic tests if needed.
Cards.Treatment: Supportive care (antipyretics, hydration).
Cards.Nursing Care: Educate families about self-limiting nature, avoid exposure to pregnant women (risk of fetal complications).
Hint: Focus on understanding the pathophysiology: Viral illness caused by parvovirus B19, leading to mild systemic symptoms and rash.
Key symptoms include: 'Slapped cheek' rash, lacy rash on body.
Remember treatments like: Supportive care (antipyretics, hydration)..

Cards.Title: Rheumatic Fever
Cards.Pathophysiology: Autoimmune reaction following Group A streptococcal pharyngitis, affecting heart, joints, and CNS.
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Polyarthritis, carditis, erythema marginatum, Sydenham chorea, subcutaneous nodules.
Cards.Diagnostics: Elevated ASO titers, Jones criteria, echocardiogram.
Cards.Treatment: Antibiotics (penicillin), anti-inflammatories (NSAIDs), long-term prophylaxis for heart involvement.
Cards.Nursing Care: Educate on completing antibiotics, monitor for cardiac complications, encourage follow-up care.
Hint: Focus on understanding the pathophysiology: Autoimmune reaction following Group A streptococcal pharyngitis, affecting heart, joints, and CNS.
Key symptoms include: Polyarthritis, carditis.
Remember treatments like: Antibiotics (penicillin), anti-inflammatories (NSAIDs).

Cards.Title: Kawasaki Disease
Cards.Pathophysiology: Systemic vasculitis of unknown cause, primarily affecting children under 5, potentially leading to coronary artery aneurysms.
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Prolonged fever (>5 days), conjunctivitis, strawberry tongue, swollen hands/feet, rash, cervical lymphadenopathy.
Cards.Diagnostics: Clinical criteria, echocardiogram for coronary artery involvement.
Cards.Treatment: IV immunoglobulin (IVIG), high-dose aspirin.
Cards.Nursing Care: Monitor cardiac status, educate parents about signs of recurrence, ensure follow-up for echocardiograms.
Hint: Focus on understanding the pathophysiology: Systemic vasculitis of unknown cause, primarily affecting children under 5, potentially leading to coronary artery aneurysms.
Key symptoms include: Prolonged fever (>5 days), conjunctivitis.
Remember treatments like: IV immunoglobulin (IVIG), high-dose aspirin..

Cards.Title: Vaccinations
Cards.Pathophysiology: Stimulate the immune system to develop immunity against specific pathogens.
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Possible mild reactions (fever, redness at injection site).
Cards.Diagnostics: N/A.
Cards.Treatment: Administer vaccines according to the CDC schedule.
Cards.Nursing Care: Educate families about vaccine importance, address concerns about side effects, monitor for anaphylaxis after administration.
Hint: Focus on understanding the pathophysiology: Stimulate the immune system to develop immunity against specific pathogens.
Key symptoms include: Possible mild reactions (fever, redness at injection site)..
Remember treatments like: Administer vaccines according to the CDC schedule..

Topic: Safety, Poisons, Communication, and Medication Administration

Cards.Title: Safety Hazards for Age Groups
Cards.Pathophysiology: Children are at risk of age-appropriate injuries due to physical and cognitive development stages.
Cards.Nursing Care: Provide education on safety measures (e.g., car seats, helmets), supervise activities, and childproof environments.
Hint: Key focus: Children are at risk of age-appropriate injuries due to physical and cognitive development stages.
Examples include: Infants: Suffocation, falls, choking., Toddlers: Poisoning, drowning, burns..

Cards.Title: Abuse
Cards.Pathophysiology: Physical, emotional, or sexual harm caused intentionally, often by caregivers or trusted individuals.
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Unexplained injuries, fear of adults, developmental delays, poor hygiene.
Cards.Diagnostics: Physical exam, history, imaging (e.g., skeletal survey for fractures).
Cards.Treatments: Remove child from harmful environment, provide psychological support, mandatory reporting.
Cards.Nursing Care: Assess for signs of abuse, ensure safety, provide resources for family counseling.
Hint: Key focus: Physical, emotional, or sexual harm caused intentionally, often by caregivers or trusted individuals.
Symptoms to note: Unexplained injuries, fear of adults.
Treatments involve: Remove child from harmful environment, provide psychological support.

Cards.Title: Corrosives
Cards.Pathophysiology: Ingestion of acidic or alkaline substances causes chemical burns to mucosal surfaces.
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Drooling, difficulty swallowing, vomiting, abdominal pain.
Cards.Diagnostics: Endoscopy to assess esophageal damage.
Cards.Treatments: Do not induce vomiting; manage airway, administer IV fluids, and consider surgery for severe damage.
Cards.Nursing Care: Educate on safe storage of household chemicals, monitor for respiratory distress, and manage pain.
Hint: Key focus: Ingestion of acidic or alkaline substances causes chemical burns to mucosal surfaces.
Symptoms to note: Drooling, difficulty swallowing.
Treatments involve: Do not induce vomiting; manage airway, administer IV fluids.

Cards.Title: Hydrocarbons
Cards.Pathophysiology: Aspiration or ingestion of hydrocarbons (e.g., gasoline, kerosene) leads to chemical pneumonitis and systemic toxicity.
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Coughing, choking, respiratory distress, CNS depression.
Cards.Diagnostics: Chest X-ray, blood gas analysis.
Cards.Treatments: Avoid inducing vomiting, provide oxygen, and manage respiratory symptoms.
Cards.Nursing Care: Educate families on safe storage, monitor for respiratory complications.
Hint: Key focus: Aspiration or ingestion of hydrocarbons (e.
Symptoms to note: Coughing, choking.
Treatments involve: Avoid inducing vomiting, provide oxygen.

Cards.Title: Salicylates
Cards.Pathophysiology: Aspirin overdose causes metabolic acidosis, respiratory alkalosis, and CNS effects.
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Tinnitus, hyperventilation, nausea, seizures.
Cards.Diagnostics: Serum salicylate levels, blood gas analysis.
Cards.Treatments: Activated charcoal, IV fluids, sodium bicarbonate for acidosis, hemodialysis in severe cases.
Cards.Nursing Care: Monitor acid-base balance, educate parents about medication safety.
Hint: Key focus: Aspirin overdose causes metabolic acidosis, respiratory alkalosis, and CNS effects.
Symptoms to note: Tinnitus, hyperventilation.
Treatments involve: Activated charcoal, IV fluids.

Cards.Title: Acetaminophen
Cards.Pathophysiology: Overdose causes liver toxicity due to glutathione depletion and accumulation of toxic metabolites.
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, jaundice (late sign).
Cards.Diagnostics: Serum acetaminophen levels, liver function tests.
Cards.Treatments: N-acetylcysteine (NAC) to replenish glutathione, supportive care.
Cards.Nursing Care: Educate on proper dosing, monitor liver function, and provide emotional support to families.
Hint: Key focus: Overdose causes liver toxicity due to glutathione depletion and accumulation of toxic metabolites.
Symptoms to note: Nausea, vomiting.
Treatments involve: N-acetylcysteine (NAC) to replenish glutathione, supportive care..

Cards.Title: Care for a Hospitalized Child
Cards.Pathophysiology: Hospitalization disrupts the child’s routine, causing stress and fear, especially regarding separation from parents and painful procedures.
Cards.Signs/Symptoms: Regression, fear, withdrawal, or aggression.
Cards.Nursing Care: Explain procedures in age-appropriate terms, offer choices when possible, and provide emotional support.
Hint: Key focus: Hospitalization disrupts the child’s routine, causing stress and fear, especially regarding separation from parents and painful procedures.
Symptoms to note: Regression, fear.
Key interventions: Encourage parental involvement., Maintain routines..

Cards.Title: Developmentally Appropriate Communication
Cards.Infants: Use soothing tones and maintain close physical contact to provide comfort.
Cards.Toddlers: Use simple words, offer choices to foster a sense of control.
Cards.Preschoolers: Use storytelling or play to explain procedures, address magical thinking.
Cards.School-Age Children: Use diagrams or demonstrations, encourage questions to reduce anxiety.
Cards.Adolescents: Communicate respectfully, include them in decision-making, address privacy concerns.

Cards.Title: Assessment Findings
Cards.Pathophysiology: Regular assessments identify deviations from normal growth and development or acute/chronic conditions.
Key Components: Toddlers/Preschoolers: Growth milestones, language skills, behavior.
School-Age/Adolescents: Physical and emotional development, scoliosis screening, sexual maturity.
Cards.Nursing Care: Use developmentally appropriate techniques, involve caregivers when assessing younger children, and document findings accurately.
Hint: Key focus: Regular assessments identify deviations from normal growth and development or acute/chronic conditions.

Cards.Title: Order of Assessment
Cards.Pathophysiology: Tailored based on the child’s age and developmental stage to reduce anxiety and ensure cooperation.
Approach: Infants: Perform auscultation and less invasive parts first; leave uncomfortable tasks (e.g., reflexes) for last.
Toddlers/Preschoolers: Allow parent involvement, use distraction, assess noninvasively first.
Older Children/Adolescents: Explain procedures thoroughly, respect privacy, and assess head-to-toe.
Hint: Key focus: Tailored based on the child’s age and developmental stage to reduce anxiety and ensure cooperation.

Cards.Title: Administering Medications
Cards.Pathophysiology: Variations in metabolism, absorption, and elimination in children require weight-based dosing and precise calculation.
Key Considerations: Oral Medications: Use syringes for accuracy, avoid mixing with essential foods.
IM/Subcutaneous: Use age-appropriate sites (e.g., vastus lateralis in infants).
IV Medications: Monitor site closely for infiltration and infection.
Cards.Nursing Care: Double-check calculations, educate parents and older children about medication use, and assess for side effects or adverse reactions.
